game:ancienttools-quickstart-text:
Ancient Tools Guide
Mortar and Pestle The classic mortar and pestle. These two tools have been in use in some form since the Paleolithic era for grinding substances such as spices and oats. To use these items in Vintage Story you must first craft each. Place the mortar on the ground then insert the pestle with . Insert any grindable item with then shift and hold to begin grinding away! Adze This adze, introduced in the Neolithic era, was a tool commonly used by ancient carpenters to shape wood into various objects or architecture. In its current implementation in the Ancient Tools mod, the adze is used to strip bark from trees. To create an adze, an adze head must first be created either through stone knapping, smelting or smithing. Craft the resulting adze head with a stick and you'll now have yourself a handy tool for collecting bark! Approach the nearest tree with adze in hand then shift and hold to begin stripping away. Stone adze heads can also be crafted with bone for an extra sturdy tool! More details about the uses for bark and stripped logs can be found in the bark stripping guide. Curing Rack Curing meats with salt is a centuries-old practice of preservation. This requires a carefully controlled environment to ensure the meat doesn't rot before the meat is cured. A cellar is recommended! A curing rack can be equipped with two hooks with . Hang any variety of salted meat(redmeat,poultry,bushmeat) and wait until your delicious meat is perfectly cured! Salted meats can also be cooked in a firepit for a quick meal solution. Native American Tanning Pre-contact Native American cultures used a different technique for tanning animal hides than colonial European settlers to create their iconic leather products. Ancient Tools implements a simplified version of this technique to give you another means of crafting leather! Want to give it a try? Visit the Native American Tanning Guide. Pitch Pitch is a sticky black substance produced by combining then melting finely powdered charcoal, tree resin, and various fibrous materials such as dry grass or dried animal feces. This material is exceptionally waterproof and sticky. Historically, it has been used to caulk the seams of wooden sailing vessels or to seal containers, such as food crocks. Ancient Tools takes advantage of its waterproof property by allowing you to use firepits, pit kilns, and forges exposed to the elements whenever pitch is used as the fuel. Additionally, pitch can be used to create long-lasting, brightly burning torches that won't be extinguished by rain. It can also be used to create chambersticks as a permenant lighting solution similar to oil lamps. Stick pitch is also a convenient alternative to glue for repairing various clutter discovered throughout the world. Simply hold a lit torch in your offhand, shift to sneak, and interact with to fix it! A detailed explanation of how to produce pitch can be found in the Pitch Guide. Note: Since resin is so integral to Ancient Tools pitch production, a system has been implemented that allows knives to scrape pine and acacia trees to create leaking logs. This system can be disabled in the mod config files. Mobile Storage There will always be a need to transport things from place to place. Cultures from ancient Greece, Egypt, Assyria, and many others all envisioned various mobile transport and storage solutions to fit the needs of their people. Hand-drawn carts were among the very first forms of man-made transport. They were often little more than a set of planks or a box placed upon a frame with wheels attached. Cheap, and often accessible to the common folk. Similarly, hand-drawn carts are the very first type of mobile storage available in Ancient Tools! More details about how to create each of these primitive vehicles and information about their usage can be found in the Mobile Storage segment.
game:ancienttools-quickstart-title-barks: Ancient Tools: Crafting Mechanic: Bark Stripping
game:ancienttools-quickstart-text-barkst:
Bark Stripping Guide
After you've aquired an adze, it's time to get stripping! The tree bark that you collect can be used for a variety of different purposes. Bark can make for an excellent firestarter in place of firewood. Or, it can be woven to create cute little bark baskets to place things in. Many barks such as birch bark and pine bark are a special arboreal resource in that they possess some unique properties that we can take advantage of. The inner layer of bark from many trees is edible and can be ground down into a flour that can then be baked into bread. This was a Scandanavian tradition of the indigenous Sami culture. There are also many barks which have medical properties which were used to treat various ailments. Have a look at the salve preparation guide if you're interested in taking advantage of them!
game:ancienttools-quickstart-title-salve: Ancient Tools: Crafting Mechanic: Salve Creation
game:ancienttools-quickstart-text-salve:
Ancient Tools Salve Creation Guide
Tree bark has had many various uses throughout history. Many trees, such as birch, pine, oak, and acacia have various beneficial healing properties. Birch is most commonly used to ease joint pain, whilst pine is most commonly used to reduce inflammation. Salves are sometimes created by homesteaders then applied to the skin to take advantage of these properties. To create a salve with Ancient Tools, first, you must convert two cooking pots into empty salve containers. This can be done by holding shift then pressing with a salve ingredient(bark, fat, or beeswax) or by crafting a cooking pot in the grid with a medicinal bark. Place both empty containers on the ground. Fill one with a single type of bark and fat, then the other with beeswax. Heat both in a firepit to convert them to prepared versions. Finally, place one prepared container on the ground then shift and hold with the other container in hand to pour them together. Congratulations, you made a healing salve! the finished salve to extract a portion that will heal over time when used. Empty salve containers can be placed in the crafting grid to convert them back into cooking pots.
game:ancienttools-quickstart-title-tanni: Ancient Tools: Crafting Mechanic: Native American Tanning
game:ancienttools-quickstart-text-tannin:
Native American Tanning Guide
Grab your nearest raw hide and let's get started! To make removal of undesirable fleshy bits easier, hides were tied into sacks with the flesh side inward and filled with water to soften the flesh. To do this, simply your hide on a water source or craft a sack using a filled bucket of water. Place the sack on the ground someplace and wait. When it is ready, it will become a soaked hide sack. While waiting it could be useful to craft up a stretching frame in preparation! Simply take the hide when it's ready and stretch it on the frame. Using a trusty knife, press shift and begin scraping away hair, fat and other undesirable materials from the hide using . The next step might sound disgusting, but it's essential to create a soft, pliable leather. We need to create a 'braining solution' to soak our hide in. Any animal brain will do. Take the brain and combine it with 10L of water in a barrel to create the solution. Now, take the hide from the stretching frame and seal it in the barrel with the braining solution you just made. This will take some time. When the hide has been thoroughly soaked in solution, the next step is to smoke the hide. This makes the hide water resistant and gives the leather its iconic golden color. Hang your hide over a fire pit and wait for it to become a smoked hide. Now, the final part! Take your smoked hide and, using a knife, carefully cut it into strips of leather. This is performed in the crafting grid.
game:ancienttools-quickstart-title-pitch: Ancient Tools: Crafting Mechanic: Pitch Creation
game:ancienttools-quickstart-text-pitch:
Pitch Guide
Pitch was once a highly saught after resource for its versatility. It could be used as a glue, a sealant, a fuel, and for many other purposes. There was no 'one way' to create pitch. Many different resources were combined for similar results. However, with Ancient Tools, you will need some charcoal, resin, and dry grass on hand for this process. To get started, you must grind two pieces of charcoal into powdered charcoal using a mortar and pestle, or any other means of grinding items. Take one piece of powdered charcoal and interact with a cooking pot using to transform the pot into an empty pitch container. Next, fill up the container using with 2 parts powdered charcoal, 4 parts resin, and 1 part dry grass. When the container is properly filled, it will convert into an unprepared pitch mixture. Now, simply pick up the mixture and heat it in the nearest firepit to create prepared pitch. When it's been finished, you can place the pot on the ground and take pieces of pitch by using a stick.
game:ancienttools-quickstart-title-woods: Ancient Tools: Crafting Mechanic: Wood Splitting
game:ancienttools-quickstart-text-woodsp:
Wood Splitting Guide
Sometimes, wooden logs are just too large to be useful. Wood splitting, otherwise known as cleaving, was a common technique for shaping wood into more usable dimensions during the Neolithic era right up until the Pre-Industrial era. To accomplish this task, many cultures drove wedges into the grain of the wood using a mallet to create smaller, yet sturdy wooden products. Similarly, wedges, either crafted from stone or forged, can be placed into any upright-standing stripped log using then smacked with a mallet with . As each quarter is split away, a fancy new beam will be yours for the taking! Beams are an essential construction component for wheels and mobile storage from Ancient Tools.
game:ancienttools-quickstart-text-mobile:
Mobile Storage
The wheel is considered by most to be the most impactful invention of human history. It is possible that the device was conceived during the late Neolithic era but, only when metal tools were more abundantly available during the Bronze era, did the wheel have a significant worldwide impact. The wheel singlehandedly revolutionized the idea of transportation across vast distances. A whole new wave of inventions were constructed to deliver objects and people from one place to another. Ancient Tools looks to incorporate a wide variety of transportation options inspired by history. Carts
Carts are simple two-wheeled constructions primarily made of wooden boards and beams that may be all a wandering trader needs in life. To build a cart of your own, all you need is a single axle, a couple of wheels, a handful of beams, and a bunch of boards arranged neatly in the crafting grid! Place the resulting cart item on the ground...and now you have a handy little device that can follow you around wherever you go, hauling all your goodies. To use the cart for its intended purpose, it will need to have an empty chest inventory placed on it with . With an inventory set on the cart, it can now be accessed with for storage purposes. To move the cart from place to place, simply pick it up by pressing shift and interacting with it using . Wherever you travel, your cart will closely follow! To put the cart down, simply repeat the same sequences of actions you used to pick up the cart. When empty, cart inventories can also be removed! Simply press ctrl, then with an empty hand to remove it from the cart.
